title: Handling Remote Data in iOS applications
content: patterns and practises in handling remote data

title: Bending the hierarchy at Honeywell
content: Using few leaves out of the book Maverick, we introduced new roles 'Associates, Coordinators and Facilitators' in a strict hierarchical organisation and were able to kickstart the transformation. In this presentation I will share some insights on how agile is perceived in such organisations and how nice it feels to bring a massive change in few months.

title: Vagmi Mudumbai
content: Dealing with large graphs using Cassandra and Titan

title: Novice Entrepreneur
content: In 2008 I went on to start a small retail enterprise which was to sell womens ethnic apparel, with a vision to make it a chain of stores across the city, multi-city, country. While I have moved on to 3 stores from one, it was a lot of learning and unlearning in the process. I will talk about my experience in setting up the enterprise, challenges, successes, ideas and in general how to break through the thought of should I really do this?

title: Micro frameworks vs Frameworks
content: Our experiences on how introducing micro frameworks at the server and client changed the development, deployment and process methodologies for our client BT.Faced with over engineered architecture with heavy frameworks we wanted to change the way typical enterprise apps were being built by going heavy on light weight frameworks (in some cases no frameworks) reducing the amount of code as well a the learning curve required to get new hands into the project.With a right mixture of javascript and java we finally got a model in place which seems to be scaling out very well.The talk aims to explain the technologies involved and the gotchas you need to look out for.

title: Design ideas that helped build Apache Hadoop
content: Hadoop has long emerged as a successful BigData platform, powering the likes of Yahoo!, Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn etc. I had the opportunity to work on Hadoop MapReduce at Yahoo! and during the time got a view into what design choices worked well to make Hadoop the highly scalable, reliable data parallel processing framework it is today. Since then, I have seen a repeat of those choices in other components that form the Hadoop eco-system like HBase, YARN etc. I would like to share some of these ideas in the talk. The format will be to talk about an idea conceptually, see its application, and describe how it worked (or in some cases, didn't) in the Hadoop components.

title: The Business of Baking : From inception to delivery
content: It all started with this elevator pitch:For two bored girls, Who liked nothing more than wasting time and eating dessert,The Business of Baking project,Is a weekend pursuit,That makes their weekend productive and hones their baking skills,Unlike their previous project - How I Met Your Mother (in loop).Find out how we used Agile to take this project from inception to delivery in two months.

title: Yes, We Kanban!
content: While providing post-production support for one of the largest delivery projects we realized that some basic things that go really well with project following XP or Scrum were absolutely not working. We then adapted Kanban for this team and this sorted out a lot of issues.Kanban is an agile approach that is gaining a lot of traction. This session is an attempt to introduce Kanban, how it helped us, its merits and how to implement it with the simplest approach. Its not about comparing Kanban with Scrum/XP and deciding which is better, rather they can complement each other and can be used in conjunction if practiced correctly.

title: Visualizations in Android - A case in Retail
content: Items:- Android Animations ( Transitions, View Flippers, etc.)- Non-Native Android libraries  using web-view- Deep Dive on user interactive Android charting libraries ( Android Plot, ChartDroid, Achartengine).This session will focus on the lessons learnt in building an android tablet app for retail command center project  with progressive disclosure of statistically heavy key performance indicators of the business.
Speaker(s): Khaarthigha S, Sri Amala Devi, Shaheedha,  PavithraK, SeshaPG, VarunVM

title: Gambling & Numbers
content: All the luck you have can't help you recognise the Math behind gambling. This presentation is about the theory of numbers that make someone's day at the casino.

title: Taming your build farm
content: An experience report from Trainline of how we have used monitoring using Nagios, Graphite and custom scripts to improve the reliability of the massive build system in Trainline. And why you shouldn't do this in your project.

title: Travel Practice
content: Over the last year, a lot of work has gone into getting domain focus around the Travel Space. We already have a number of clients in this space viz. Trainlne, SouthWest, TripAdvisor,Delta,Backkick, lastminute.com to name a few.This presentation would give an overview of the travel space, trends in the travel industry, where ThoughtWorks can help companies in this space as well as the groundwork we have put in to identify potential customers in this space.This will be driven by Manjari from Pune and Vinod from Bangalore.

title: Story map
content: Story map brings a different perspective in to detailing out high to low level mapping of user goals to user stories. The focus is to ensure that the goals are met for a user persona. It also helps in prioritising requirements and sets milestone for the business. Benefits of using story mapping: * Provides a birds eye view to a detailed view, including user journey * Helps us and business to prioritize and groom your backlog visually* Visible way to approach a MVP * Helps in managing  and discussing scope* Helps in tracking feature completeness* Helps in release planning * One of the activity which can be used in an Inception

title: pradarshan ke tarikey..
content: Know newer & better ways of performing showcases.

title: Beyond MoSCoW - Prioritization techniques for project teams
content: Have you ever been in a prioritization discussion where the only priorities are High, Higher, and Highest? Or tried using MoSCoW to prioritize user stories only to find that 80% of the cards are 'Must Have'? In this workshop, we show you how you can effectively use a gamut of different prioritization methods, ranging from simple techniques like stacked ranking or MoSCoW that classify items along a single dimension to multi-dimensional techniques like priority quadrants, Story Maps, and Innovation Games. We'll be pruning feature trees, spending fake currency, using visual metaphors and having fun, while truly identifying what the most important stuff really is. We also show you how you can choose which prioritization techniques may work best for different settings, group sizes, and personality mixes.

title: The Wizard of Oz experiment
content: The Wizard of Oz experiment was a term coined by John F Kelly around 1980 for describing the method used by him in creating a natural language processing system. He was able to create a processing system that far exceeded the language processing system of those times.  As part of this presentation I will : 1. Introduce the concept . 2. Explain how its being used and promoted in the Lean Start up Methodology by Eric Ries ( of The Lean Start up fame ) and others. 3. Conclude it with a real life example of how a start up used the 'Wizard of Oz' experiment to test some of their hypothesis.

title: Building MPP Data Warehouse Solutions with PostgreSQL and Stado (GridSQL)
content: Exponential growth of data over the last few years have always stressed upon needs of a better data systems with an expectation to crunch billions of rows of data in a shorter span. In this talk, we will focus on building a Massively Parallel Processing (MPP) system with PostgreSQL and Stado (fork of GridSQL) that could meet this expectation. The system is capable of scaling horizontally by parallelizing queries among multiple server instances which helps us to take advantage of multicore systems (and clusters of them) instead of relying on a traditional one query - one process paradigm. Awesome support from the PostgreSQL community and continuous improvements made to the PostgreSQL engine, simply adds more spices to this mix.

title: The Science of Fast Bowling and Send the Stumps Flying
content: The Aspects of Fast Bowling ,  Bowling Techniques , Physical & Psychological Preparation for play .  How to prevent Injuries.  Not only for cricket lovers but for all.

title: Large Format Photography
content: I have been doing a lot of film photography lately. I have also started shooting large format which is a whole new world of photography.Large format photography involves shooting completely manually on a big wooden camera using 4x5" sheet film. I will explain & demonstrate the the workings of the camera, the process of developing the negative and the process of making a final print.

title: Vagrant Up & Running
content: Using Vagrant and chef-solo to automate devbox setup, ensuring anybody can start working within an hour on any project. The  advantages of developing on a virtual box which resembles the production environment very closely. Never again will you hear, "But all tests did pass on my machine" or a "Which version of postgres are you on?".  Also, using chef to extend your dev box config to your QA environment and even production.

title: How to make ideas stick
content: A quick review of the book on the same name, We can understand what makes some ideas easier to sell than others and apply the same when we communicate some of our own ideas with the same elements that sticky ideas have.

title: Validate your product idea without spending a fortune!
content: Do you have a product idea? Are you perplexed with the thought of it being "an idea with potential?" Well, where do I start? How do I measure if my idea has any potential? If you've answered any of these questions with "Yes", this talk is for you!"Idea is not a penny worth without validation and execution!"All of us often have good (potentially great!) product ideas but the biggest barrier is actually early validation of these ideas. This talk will highlight few tools to validate your product idea without spending a fortune or months to validate the proposition, all it takes is less than 24 hrs! We'll also look at an example of using these tools on a "real world product idea".

title: "RTI Activism and Whistle Blowers"
content: This presentation will focus on the powerful tool called RTI that has been used to expose  the correct/incorrect way of the functioning of the government and various public agencies. We would also like to touch upon the RTI crusaders & Whistle blowers, who have been killed for standing up for what is right. Additionally, we would also be briefly talk about some of the Public Interest Litigation activists who file cases in the court for the society's well being. Why do we want to talk about this?To bring better awareness about RTI and be a more socially responsible ThoughtWorker.

title: Are office wide fun events necessary ?
content: I love volunteering to office wide events, merely because I get to meet a lot of people and love the energy and enthusiasm around the events. After volunteering for multiple such events, I realise that there is a shift in the way events happen in TW. This talk will be case study and visualization based on the data i collected from volunteering for one such event in Chennai Office and the emerging trends around the people participation.

title: Are you the weakest link?
content: Did you know:* What are the 25 worst passwords you could use?* The most pirated video in 2012?* How to protect the myriad of passwords we use to access our online accounts?* How we almost lost a customer because of a security incident?* How one of our colleagues had his salary account cleaned out because of an online fraud?Join me in an interactive workshop to demonstrate what you need to know about Information Security at ThoughtWorks.

title: HIVE workshop to design a bigdata warehouse
content: Hive, an essential tool in the Hadoop ecosystem that provides an SQL (Structured Query Language) dialect for querying data stored in the Hadoop Distributed Filesystem (HDFS). Most data warehouse applications are implemented using relational databases that use SQL as the query language. Hive lowers the barrier for moving these applications to Hadoop. People who know SQL can learn Hive easily. Without Hive, these users must learn new languages and tools to become productive again. Similarly, Hive makes it easier for developers to port SQL-based applications to Hadoop, compared to other tool options. Without Hive, developers would face a daunting challenge when porting their SQL applications to Hadoop.In this session we will cover setting up a local hadoop cluster, run hive queries and an application to explore the features of Hive. I will provide a VM to setup the individual's machines before coming to the workshop.

title: Taking TWU to Samsung
content: I am conducting a TWU style training at Samsung, Seoul, South Korea. This is a first of its kind engagement to provide Agile training. This is a first for ThoughtWorks and also for Samsung. I would be sharing my experience of the engagement and what I learnt from it.

title: Building a multi-tenant Hadoop cluster for real world use
content: Abstract: Hadoop is more than just wordcount on MapReduce and HDFS. To build real world hadoop applications for large organisations one needs to think about a lot more issues:(a) How do applications integrate with Hadoop ? The entire architecture will include a lot more components that bring data in / out of a Hadoop cluster, components that provide services on top of MapReduce and HDFS, etc.(b) What issues occur in a multi-tenant Hadoop cluster ? How does one handle them ? (c) What kind of monitoring makes sense for maintaining such a cluster ?At a client organisation we are working with, just such an environment has been created and is in production use. We would like to share our learnings in this tech talk. It will include a description of various components of Hadoop eco-system (and some outside) that fit in such a place, the kind of practises and solutions one needs to employ to support such a cluster.

title: Web application hacking - Exploiting common security vulnerabilities of websites
content: I would like to share my experiences of hacking web sites / applications.The talk would include how to find vulnerabilities, information leakage of website with Google without using any other tool than browser.I would also like to share how even popular / big websites have very trivial vulnerabilities. The talk would include a demo or practical session.

title: Learning the fun way - Games and Activities
content: I believe that we can get our point across easily through an activity or a game. And since the participant is also thoroughly involved in it, the learnings are self derived and stay with him for long.In last year and half, I have come across multiple such techniques through consulting and training engagements. I will be sharing quite a few of these techniques and games. Participants can then employ them during inceptions, facilitation, retrospectives, trainings or any other workshop.Here are some examples - Bingo as a game for Word recall for new concepts taught, Dumb charades for word or concept recall, Jumping for answering a yes or no quiz, lots of energizers and so on.This will be a workshop when I will share these games and techniques and we all will have fun!!!

title: Suncorp-Oracle Engagement: Challenges and Learnings
content: The Suncorp-Oracle consulting engagement, to the best of my knowledge, is the first engagement in TWI where a consultant was assigned by a client (Suncorp) to work with their vendor (Oracle) for Agile adoption and facilitating distributed development. The challenges of having to work with 2 organizations having different cultures and policies are quite unique, as compared to a client only consulting engagement.I plan to share the challenges which I encountered on the engagement and also how did I address the challenges.

title: Story of Abworks
content: The Abcam programme of work is in a rarified league of [TW] projects where a lot of dynamics are introduced as opposed to other [relatively smaller] projects that we usually undertake. Some of the challenges deal with multiple parallel teams developing and still interacting with each other, their own flavor of blue-green deployments (specific to PWS), replatforming from a legacy tech stack, multiple apps stitched together to provide the current user experience - even within the same user interface, etc.Other topics: Their definition of devops/webdev/blue owls.
Speaker(s): Sairam Krish, Vijay Aravamudhan, Sasikumar T, Vidya D, Nithya N, Kulvinder S

title: Mathematical Image Generation
content: Learn how using mathematics is a cool and fun way to generate arts, designs, even photo realistic images!Break the barrier between code and image,  the barrier between moving from image to animation, image to video.View Time as just yet another variable to make wonders.Connect the dots between code - image - graphics - video - film!Learn to put your GPUs to a great use!

title: Concept to Product in 60 days!
content: An idea most often remain just that. A dead insipid lump presented in a tray of gold! Until the moment comes for it to start breathing life. That is when banality ceases to be silly and suddenly begin to look profound. The joy and excitement is however more pronounced in the journey of bringing the idea to life. This is about one such journey where a thought residing in the darkest of spaces (somewhere inside the human hair) started to reverberate with life. From modest and humble beginnings rose the idea of presenting an interface for a Retail buyer (the target customer) to make wise and opportune decisions in keeping with the ever changing business needs of today's retail world. The choice of platform dictated by organisational need, (wanting to gear up on Android skills), the way ahead was thrown wide open for the team to explore the unchartered territory of retail and Android (both the domain being equally new). What began with the simple goal of helping a Retail buyer choose a product's "best price" transformed to a multi functional tool presenting the buyer with the most important levers required to do their day to day job making it a one stop place for the buyer to be!Any effort is only as good as the acceptance it receives from the target group. So when the largest gathering of retailers in the world (NRF) acknowledged and applauded what they saw, it was a vindication of the team's untiring efforts and the validation of an idea which matured to form a first of it's kind Thoughtworks initiative - a full fledged business product platform! Come be a part of our journey. Experience bliss and software blitzkrieg!

title: 50 stories in 15 minutes !
content: How to effectively use a story map format to identify stories, and using an effective template to capture story details. This session can help a BA come up with a story map and identify stories on the basis of the story map - especially useful when you are  working on a time crunched proposal / inception when story identification needs to happen quick and fast, while also ensuring that the stories are of the right size !

title: Time Management for Dummies
content: Based on my experience with multi tasking, I intend to provide some tips and tricks as to how to effectively manage time. The session will provide the audience with hints on how they can prioritize their various activities, and how to manage and track their progress, as well as when to delegate to others ! This session is a based on practical life experience, and can be applied in context of projects too !

title: Making Sense of the Big Data: A  Market Perspective
content: My presentation will focus only on the business side of Big Data. It will seek to answer the following questions:What does the market look like currently? What is the industry and market segmentation? Who is doing what and why? How is the industry likely to emerge over next few years?What skills will be in demand?There is a lot of hype about Big Data in the market. My presentation will be an attempt to clear the fog and present in clear and easy to understand way about this industry.

title: First flight as a UI developer
content: The story of 2 grads hatched out of the TWU hatchery and their flight into becoming UI-Developers. They knew very little about the UI world but thanks to a few experienced ones they took their first flight and now have been left alone to explore this beautiful World of UI Development. Fly-Away......they said.

title: Head First TW
content: TWU 28 was the largest TWU batch ever- and it's half way through it's first year in TW. Looking back we've got 92 stories (don't worry we won't take too long) to talk about, all having the following in common-- TWU- Yin and Yang - the beach and some of the toughest projects we've been on- Working with the smart alecks, smart asses and the bad asses- Talking TW history with the veterans- and making some history too- Discovering TW and ourselvesAnd concluding with a little before and after

title: Abstractions: Lessons from Origami
content: Abstraction in art is artist's impression of the object/situation. It may or may not look similar to original object but surely remind the viewer of the original object.In context of origami, the real life objects e.g. elephants are very difficult to recreate because one can not add or remove material. So artist's get around by creating models which highlight part of object they fit. Since the model is perception of artist, artists have created 50 models to represent elephant. This analogy is equally applicable to software . Software artisan's are trying to model real world and find it equally daunting to think about the models. May be we can borrow a lesson or two from origami artists to shape our thinking.

title: A Drunkard's Walk: Role of Chance in Life
content: A drunkard's walk AKA random walk has significant impact in our lives. Often the role played by chance is overlooked in heroics and personal abilities. Often times success is attributed to ability. But ability does not guarantee achievement, nor is achievement proportional to ability. And so it is important to always keep in mind the other term in the equation - the role of chance.I want to highlight key excepts from Leon Mlodinow's book. This book has a great influence on me and changed my outlook to life considerably.

title: My TW journey
content: What a coincidence, I joined exactly 1 year back and I get an email which says I can talk about it! It shall happen.

title: My first year at ThoughtWorks
content: I would like to talk on the following with respect to my first year at TW:My experience at ThoughtWorks. How TW gave me a sense of responsibility and self confidence.My meetings with the TW leaders. Inspiring talk by Roy.The food.The team outings, Chennai 150.The VodQA events.

title: Short Circuits to fixing bugs
content: The roller coaster ride  of an electronics engineer into the new and beautiful world of software full of lots and lots of learning and some difficult moments and so much fun in TWU and the project team. How the people around me helped me learn various things, supported me and how I embarrassed myself at times. All in all, FUN TIMES !!

title: First memorable Year at Thoughtworks.
content: * My Experience in my first project.* Experience with Agile based projects.* Opportunity i had to fix defects being a QA.* Experience about outing, Retro's .* Experience in working in a transparent company.

title: Performance Driven Design
content: Borrowing the term from its famous cousine for performance this time. So How do we get to drive design from performance aspects1. Determine right concurrency - Number of simultaneous users is not concurrency2. Identify system bottlenecks with empirical data and queuing models3. Cross verifying performance requirements with business requirements. Trust me it is hard to have this conversation but easy for developers to figure out.4. Making sense of system matrices such as CPU usage, Memory usageSo, in my session, I want to briefly touch upon techniques such as queuing theory, workload modeling and performance modeling which can be used to uncover vital clues for design.

title: Our First Year Experiences
content: Sandesh Aravind, Anand Santhanam & Swaminathan Ganesan from PAM team would present our first year experiences at TW
Speaker(s): Sandesh Aravind, Anand Santhanam & Swaminathan Ganesan

title: WTF- Where are The Freshers?
content: June 2012. The ThoughtWorks offer letter in my hands. I am happy. I am scared. My friends are in advice-giving mode: Oh Dear!! You are joining as fresher, make sure you pass the post-training testNobody lets a newbie work, you are going to do nothing for next 2 yearsYou need to work really hard to prove yourself. Be aware of all the politics involvedOffice life is crazy for freshersFirst impression is the last impressionBut now, as a ThoughtWorker with 8 months in, my first question to myself is "Am I REALLY a Fresher?"" And, the answer is interesting. I have attended Psychotic & Fun training in TWU.  I have been supported by many ThoughtWorkers. I have gotten equal opportunities. I have had tough times. I have had easy times. I have had learning times. I have had fun times.But with great fun, comes great responsibilities. I am expected to BE  a "ThoughtWorker"When people ask me "In the last 8 months, what do I think about  ThoughtWorks", all I end up saying is:  "There are no freshers in ThoughtWorks"Isn't that good? Well  only ThoughtWorkers say a Yes

title: Continuous Monitoring
content: Feedback is an important aspect of learning. Many a time its rather more important than what one is learning. In many big and small software projects that we have worked on, quick feedback has enabled our team to predict and react to critical issues faster, while lack of feedback has lead us astray. We believe that there is a constant struggle on our delivery teams between 'informed decisions' and 'uninformed guesses'. Our talk aims to influence ThoughtWorkers to start and keep monitoring their code, and how their code interacts with infrastructure, external systems from the day they start coding, the so called i0, so as to make more of 'informed decisions' and less of 'uninformed guesses'.We would like to do this using simple time-series visualisation tools like Graphite, and complex log aggregation composites like logstash+Kibana+elasticSearch.

title: Influencing Effectively
content: Ever had a great idea but couldn't get the rest of your team on board? Or tried to change team/people mindsets, but were too set in their ways to heed your call?I have been thinking about influence quite a lot recently. Want to share some learnings I have had on what worked and what didn't and would like to pose more questions for people to reflect on.

title: Simple and Effective Research Techniques
content: Everyone needs to do research to be effective at what they do. If you are in Sales and Marketing, you need research to reach out to right target audience. If you are in recruitment, you need to reach out to the right audience. If you are a developer or a QA, you need good research as well.This session will focus on using simple, effective techniques using free to use tools to make you spend minimum time and get the maximum juice from the time you spend on research. Focus will be on tools like Linkedin, Advanced Google Search and some other free to use tools.

title: Recursion and self-reference - GEB
content: How self-reference and formal rules allow systems to acquire meaning despite being made of "meaningless" elements. What is a Strange Loop?

title: Can a Mobile App Crash paralyze your revenues ?!
content: How do you feel when, your tech advanced phone which you flaunt, is not able to do elementary essential things in â€œcertainâ€ù circumstances? Just because the apps were not fabricated to perform under extreme conditions. For instance you are about to reach the notch of your favorite game and just a step away from the highest score ever, suddenly the game closes, and that too â€œAll by itself â€ù. Everybody hates this situation, you become just â€œHelplessâ€ù. And so, I am going to talk about the impact of Mobile app crash on your businessâ€™ value chain, emphasizing on how can it screw your current and future revenues?

title: "Distributed Agile" Analytics
content: Working with a client on a distributed BI analytics project, as a coach, I found some interesting challenges in writing stories, managing the team, work sharing. I will share my experience on what the challenges were, and how we approached the solution. This session will have less to do with coaching/ consulting and more to do with the actual delivery challenges faced by the team.

title: First year at TW
content: Sharing our experiences from through TWU....and beyond!!

title: Story walls are boring, what's next?
content: Imagine you have a dedicated space in a client office to work on a cool product idea:Setting up story walls is like 1960's, don't just occupy the wall space with story cards, here's how to create an experience, make a buzz! (My experience report from one of the coolest innovation lab engagement I worked on in UK!)

title: "Project without boundaries -- BAs code, QAs develop, Devs cuke, Tech Lead Missing!"
content: Ever thought what will happen without a full-time tech lead on your project? Would life be simpler without an actual client there to bug you always? What will happen if all the QAs take over development and push the devs to write cukes? Will there be any stories if the BA gets down to writing code? We will be answering all these questions and much more with our experience on TTA, a beach project here in pune. We will talk about our experiences, fresh out of the oven, the practices that we created, how we got around to it and much more...We 3 speakers will be talking about it from a Dev, QA and BA's perspective...

title: "TTA: A view is worth a 1000 Failing Tests"
content: Test Trend Analyzer is a product, tightly coupled with CI to help you analyse your tests. Its aim is to bring out pretty visuals of not so pretty tests.It provides an easy insight into your test failures, so that you do not need to dig into the console log or log files to find the reason.Ever wondered how painless it will be if you get a visual to find defects, or health of the project?Yes!! TTA gives you those visuals. On the consumer front, TTA consumes xUnit/nUnit based results and other raw data from across your projects and test frameworks and archives it. On the view front, TTA provides some simple reports, and a way to create custom reports that displays Test Trends for you.By consuming result, we mean it consumes the logs every time you run tests to give you views that your project can get benefits from.Get to know how a team of newbies designed this.

title: Information Architecture: Techniques and best practices
content: Information architecture is an area of User Experience which is often overlooked during the application design. We'd want to introduce by explaining why Information architecture (IA) is important for organising the content of any application. We'll focus on the methods and techniques for IA design and take a look at the most common and useful IA patterns. We'll also be talking about the best practices and walk through some case studies and real world examples.

title: Always expect the unexpected!
content: What are the top ten blunders you can make within your first year at ThoughtWorks? We give you bizarre ways of how we've followed Murphy's Law (Anything that can go wrong, will go wrong) by the book! From freak accidents to being pranked, from pantry disasters to budding guitarists -  our first few months have been quite the riot at ThoughtWorks. Find out with us how our faux pas have actually helped us make friends and become full fledged ThoughtWorkers now!

title: Them Studios Bloodsuckers!
content: or, why you don't receive more productivity allowances :)This talk aims to explain how Studios works, both from a business and a technical standpoint. We will explain our experiences in the products domain and contrast it with how this is different from our experiences in the services world. If you've ever had questions such as "how come you guys...?" or "you guys should...", then this is the talk to be at. Actually, if you've sufficiently sized voodoo dolls, this might still be the talk to be at.
Speaker(s): Srijayanth Sridhar, Shilpa Goley, Darshana Radhakrishnan

title: How StackOverflow changed my life
content: This is my story of how answering questions at StackOverflow helped me to learn, help and be thanked. This is story of how StackOverflow changed my life.

title: Twist Your Tails Off
content: This is a hands on workshop for Twist. Twist has been around a few years and not enough people in ThoughtWorks know about it. This despite the fact that Twist has over a hundred customers currently.As a participant, you will understand why domain language is important, why the ability to refactor from domain language is powerful, and the language to communicate to others the value of Twist. There might be T-shirts too... ;)

title: Retail Failures - Why I think they are failing..
content: Retailers today focus so much on building cool apps to improve their social presence but forget the 2 most basic aspects of retailing - Merchandising & Inventory Management.This has been my pet peeve and feel this is the root cause for retail failures.As part of this lightning talk, I want to present this trend and see if it ignites a few thoughts amongst TWers...

title: Musicalia
content: Can anybody learn music? I've been performing an experiment in TW offices trying to see if I can get just about anyone to pick up a guitar and learn music. While the project is ongoing, I have experiences I'd like to share.If you would like to learn how music works, how you can deconstruct the process and even teach yourself some, then please do attend. At the least, I promise you'll listen to exciting music.

title: Varnam - the multi-lingual predictive transliterator
content: There are currently no open source solutions available to do predictive transliteration for Indian languages. Google offers one, but none that are open source. More importantly, support for Indian languages are terrible.I have written a transliterator which is cross platform and can be used across several languages. I would like to talk about how this solution is architected, what challenges I've faced and why I think this is useful.I will also talk about integrating this library with a NodeJS application, writing an asynchronous Node module and serving requests with good response time.

title: Pugaipadam - Digital Photo Wall
content: Pugaipadam is a Tamil word that translates to photograph. As the name clearly suggests, we are building an awesome one stop area that has a lot to do with photographs. Problem Statement: At ThoughtWorks Chennai, there is a photo wall on the way to the cafeteria that is updated only periodically. Also, any TWer who needs to know about another TWer has to look at different places: Jigsaw, myThoughtWorks and GAB for example. Solution: Pugiapadam is a digital photo wall, where anyone within an office can view anyone else's profile with relative ease. The main features of this wall are as follows: 1. TWer's Photo(s)2. Few important data points from Jigsaw(eg - skills, years of exp, role, grade, etc....)3. Filter the list of  TWers by role/project4. Contact information5. Their content- blogs and any other personal informationWe hope to present a unique and stylish wall that will work towards better enablement of TWers with respect to people search.

title: Inception workshop: Non/Cross functional requirement gathering
content: - Learn how to capture all Non functional, Cross functional and Continuous Deployment requirements during inception. - Ge into multiple group, take case study, use ThoughtWorks branded cards to learn each â€˜bilityâ€™ of the system, identify what is required & applicable to the system we are building, create stories for that. - I have been using this technique for almost 3-4 inception and worked out really really well for me.

title: Why is Responsive Web Design so important for any new web application?
content: This session is all about starting from basic on advance techniques used in RWD.* Is RWD new or solving very old problem in new way?* What are the different type of content needs RWD?* Approach on handling different types for content with RWD? * Why it is important to do Mobile First while approaching to RWD?* Some cool examples what we are doing at SONY

title: Selling Scala (NEW technology stack) to clients?
content: Want to share my experience with selling Scala/Play framework at SONY. What all we prepared?How did we do?What are the criteria/points we discussed while considering new tech stack?

title: The six hats I wear
content: Using Edward de Bonoâ€™s term 'Six thinking hats', I explore six facets to Internal Communication. Itâ€™s a new role - a new piece in the ThoughtWorks puzzle. As someone from a completely different background (Read: clinical psychology), what lessons am I learning from a fascinating job like this? Explore the world of internal communication through the six thinking hats Iâ€™m learning to wear!

title: Playing With Future
content: We have been using Play framework with Scala for the Sony project in Pune. The Play framework allows you to desing the entire web app in a non-blocking fashion: be it request-response cycles, mongdodb calls (via reactivemongo) or webservice calls. But unlike callback based systems like node.js, Play offers a different type of abstraction called Futures. This talk will share our expereince of using Future based design for Sony project. It will cover aspects like:	- what are futures?	- how to write code which invlove composing futures in the real world applications?	- how to synchronize futures without blocking?	- how do futures enable implicit paralellism?	- how to test such code?	- and most importantly, what are the pitfalls of this approach?

title: Getting rid of I from DI
content: Dependency injection is considered essential to designing applications that are easy to test. This is certainly true in languages like Java and C# where construtor based injection has become an accepted best practice. It turns out that this presumption is a result of limited object-orientated capabilities of the host language. In a fully object-oritented languages which support modules and mixins, this form of DI can be replaced with name based compile-time dependency resolution mechanism without a need for external frameworks. We are using this approach on Sony project in Pune which is based on Scala and Play. Not only has it worked fantastically for us, it has ensured that our classes do not have constructors, hence nothing to inject! This approach allows extreme flexibility in refactoring which is diffcult to imagine with other DI frameworks. We will share how to use this pattern in Scala, how to test such code, what are tradeoffs and how does it compare with traditional approaches.

title: Journey from Java to Scala/Play during SONY inception
content: During a recent inception for Sony, our team manage to convince customer to use Scala and Play instead of Java with a traditional web framewrok. It is an interesting case study on how onsite inception team worked with the offshore team to build enough data points to support this pitch. We will walk you through the experience and the lessons learnt. We will also discuss and debate the same pitch with the audience. Those of you who are trying to get work based on cool technologies like Scala/Play should find this talk extremely useful. Sunit recently blogged about the whole thing here:https://my.thoughtworks.com/blogs/sunit/2013/03/05/journey-from-java-to-scala-and-play-framework-during-sony-inception

title: Mobile testing - The good, the bad, the ....
content: Are you looking for help in how to go about doing Mobile testing? How is it different that the usual testing that we do ?How to manage testing on multiple devices and browsers?What are tools for automation ?How to go about automating the Hybrid mobile app?What are the things that needs to be focused more ?We had similar questions got answers to some. Also some practices that we followed helped us deliver an App and website live successfully.

title: 45 mins to cloudify your device testing
content: Have you ever contributed to mobile app development/testing? if the answer is yes then you know the pain of running tests on all the devices under the sun ,some of them are so archaic that museums honor them and few of them on the other hand are still in the brains of business development manager of a device manufacturing company.You need to serve them all without using telepathy.Smart testers can do much more when we minimize the hassle of procuring,deploying and maintaining dozens of mobile devices.Lets dive into "What","Why" and "How" of cloud based device testing and monitoring services.What you can start realizing after this session: 1.What goes inside a good enterprise mobile testing solution?2.Factors to consider before selecting a cloud based solution.3.Answer to "Do I still need that"?4.Approaches to implement cloud based device testing.5.Solution Providers and Products.

title: Playing with Future (Non-blocking architecture using Scala, Akka & Play)
content: Based on our experience working on SONY project using Play 2.1 & Scala,* What is non-blocking architecture? Why is this so important?* What are the advantages and in what cases this will be really useful?* How do we achieve non-blocking using Scala, Akka and Play framework? Are there any alternatives for this?* What are the pitfalls and what to watch out for when using this kind of architecture.* How do we really test this? Is it easy or difficult or just different?* Some cool features in Play framework v2.1 and testing aspect

title: Our response to RFPs  â€“ Progressive or Painful?
content: This session will aim at talking about the common issues faced by team across India when they respond to proposals â€“ in terms of Â·        ContextÂ·        TimelineÂ·        Team compositionÂ·        ScopeÂ·        Expectation setting (with the client and within the TW team)Â·        Contribution by individual roles. This presentation will be based on data collected from proposal teams across India in the past one year and the goal will be to identify common patterns and ways to handle issue
Speaker(s): Dhivya Arunagiri, Sasikala Mahesh, Kalaiarasi Ramanan

title: Storyboarding and paper prototyping
content: The idea is to briefly introduce the process of storyboarding and why it is effective in focusing on the goal and getting everyone on the same page without directly arriving at interface level solutions. We'll be taking a sample problem and work in teams to collaborate on the storyboard creation. We'll also be introducing techniques and tools to quickly come up with paper wireframes. Some focus will also be on how to present the paper wireframes to validate usability.

title: 20 things you must do before leaving ThoughtWorks
content: You must have heard the top 20 songs of the month. 20 best movies of the year.20 things you must do before you die. 20 books you must read. 2013 being the 20th aniversary of ThoughtWorks, we will take you through 20 things you MUST DO as a ThoughtWorker, in lightning  speed. There must be at least a few things on that list that you would have not done. Let us help you explore that!!!!

title: Profiling and optimizing your apps for performance
content: As the browsers get powerful by the day, we often tend to overlook how our code performs. We'll be starting off with an introduction to the factors which affect the application performance. The primary focus will be to walk through a sample app, introduce and use different tools to measure the performance metrics and then come up with ways and approaches to optimize with visible results in performance.

title: Walk, Jog, Run
content: Why am I walking? I need to run.Where to start?What NOT to optimize, and what to.Build on other's learnings.Performance vs 'X'Need to break barriers, break beliefsPrevention is better than ITCHINGArms and ammunition

title: Performance tuning of Hybrid mobile apps
content: We(IBA readers Team) released a hybrid mobile application to read magazines on mobile platform iOS and android and we came across lot of performance/scalability problems.We solved these problems and would like to share this knowledge with everyone.It will mainly focus on:1.Slow webkit/javascript engine2.Memory management3.Tools and techniques to do performance benchmarking/remote debugging.4.Continuous  delivery of iOS,android(code signing,Over the air distribution)5.Lazy loading/unloading6.MVC frameworks performance analysis

title: Learnings from testing "Real Time Auction" system
content: Livesale automation is a custom test automation framework developed to test online car auction/bidding system developed for OVE as part of Simulcast Everywhere project. During the course of this presentation we would like to talk about:Challenges	- Simulating multi-user interaction	- Single action resulting in different manifestations for various users	- Low maintenance, able to cope up with In-Cycle test automation	- Robust	- Configurable, multiple environments	- Functional performance tracking as a stop gap measure to counter the lack of performance testingPhilosophy	- Behaviour Driven Testing	- DRY	- Abstraction	- Enforcing the correct definition of done across the teamFeatures	- Testing user journeys rather than specific functional requirement	- Declarative Scenarios	- Automated simulation of an online auction where various roles(Buyers, Sellers, Auctioneer) interact simultaneously   	- Functional performance tracking	- Enforce abstractions to remain dry	- Soft assertions, reporting, recording test data and data management	- Concurrency at scenario and step level	- Long running test to simulate production saleTech Stack	- Cucumber	- Capybara	- Selenium Webdriver	- Ruby	- ActiveRecord	- Selenium Grid

title: Mobile design pitfalls
content: We'll be talking about common design patterns in mobile apps and why taking general web design patterns to the mobile isn't a good idea. We'll be looking at many applications and identifying some antipatterns and suggesting better and more usable approaches to the problems.

title: Linux Server Hardening
content: Talk about the hardening steps for Linux servers as prescribed by the Information Security team.

title: Automating mobile app testing the Calabash way.
content: In this world of smartphones, there is an app for almost everything possible under the sun. Testing them on the plethora of mobile devices available can be a pain, right?Solution? Well there are many, but one such is Calabash.Calabash is an open-source, automated testing technology for Android and iOS native and hybrid applicationsThis one is easy-to-learn and easy-to-use . The way Cucumber is used in automating web, its cucurbitaceae family member Calabash will help you do the same with Android and iOS, leveraging the BDD way. Learn more about the offerings of this technology which include a console for faster development, running tests on emulators and actual devices, and many more.

title: Rothschilds, The Secret Government
content: A small number of extremely wealthy people, descendants of wealthy families in Europe and the U.S, own a major part of the material wealth of the world. This power is concentrated in London which is the centre of the world banking system. The control they exercise is kept within the original families and passed down from generation to generation. They are highly organised, operating in secret through a web of 'private' organisations. The Rothschilds is one such family that established a dynasty starting in the late 18th century. They established banking and communication network in major cities across the world while keeping the business a family matter. This gave them power to influence the world finance, consequently the goverments, and thereby manipulate international affairs.During the talk I will quickly cover:- The Global Elite- History of Rothchilds- Dynasty and influence on global finance- Evidence in support of the theory

title: The Super Daddy of All Hybrid Mobile Architectures
content: We challenge you to spot the difference between a hybrid and a native app! Can't do it? We'll show you how you can build this mirage. Learn about a hybrid architecture that allows sharing of application logic across various mobile platforms along with the ability to leverage native components. Even better, you could pick and choose what's shared and what's native. And while you're at it, don't compromise on the native look and feel and yet get a mobile web app for free.This is Calatrava Magic. A bridge-architecture based approach which spawned from Delta Airline's requirement of extending their existing native Apps with features that needed to be built just once for all the platforms. Witness the power with your own eyes through the demo of the Apps we've built with this framework. You can take our word, this is as native as web gets.

title: Speeding up your Android emulator
content: Tired of the ultra-slow android ARM emulator, but can't do without it because of Google APIs? Want to leverage the speed of the Intel Atom one? Come and find out a simple way to tweak android emulators.

title: From Chennai to Kampala - how we helped deliver TW East Africa's first billable project
content: Elucidating experiences on the field and the impact of NGO's beauracratic nature. We would also touch upon the intricacies of supporting a globally dispersed open source community to move in pace with a dedicated team. A peek into the usage of  RapidFTR as a service and its support to mobile as a client in both offline and online modes. The indispensable challenge of handling large amounts of data on the mobile. Also the impending future of RapidFTR's evolution into a platform to be able to support multiple modules like birth registration system,etc

title: CHAOTIC SOFTWARE
content: Chaos plays a fundamental role in the universe and it explains the behaviour of complex systems such as the way birds fly in flocks and how we evolve.Even the Indian cricket team is chaotic !!! What, you may ask, has it got to do with software development? Everything actually. Agile software development follows a natural, evolving, chaotic cycle. The smallest variation in conditions can result in a massive difference in outcome. The talk will revolve around how we can harness the chaos strategy to create better organisations and software.
Speaker(s): Yahya Poonawala, Trishna Mohanty, Harsha Chaudhary

title: A Dietician's Guide to the Buffet
content: Heisenberg's uncertainty principle asserts that it is impossible to measure accurately a particle's position and velocity at the same time.  If you get a handle on one, the other escapes your grip.  Program managers wanting to build efficient and effective IT systems face a similar conundrum.  If they get a handle on the cost of implementation, the lose the grip on business value.  And if they want to drive by business value, they end up wanting to satisfy everyone and everything and cost spirals up. In effect, the minimum viable product has become almost an oxymoron. You have either minimum or viable, never both.  Quite a hard puzzle to crack.Here's an approach that takes a step towards solving this puzzle.  With business priority as the key lever, we establish a pecking order for program managers on what projects to do and in what order - so that it drives maximum business value within optimal costs.   This presentation takes a shot at solving this puzzle with a model and approach that could let program managers have the cake and eat it too.

title: Programming for all: Birth to Coma in 40 days.
content: It all started with a simple mail thread.We started a new stuff in Chennai,  an initiative to help everyone learn programming. From all paths of life (Admin, QAs, BAs, PMs, Research and Recruitment) showed interest and it started as any other initiative. Will be sharing how it started, it's current status, what might happen and my learnings.

title: My First Year at TW
content: My First Year at TW

title: Five months into learning and failing fast
content: How does it feel to move out of home for the first time on your birthday? What to expect when you have to stay with not just unknown people but with unknown people from a different nation all together. How does the transition from college to office feel? Being at ThoughtWorks University- learning with fun and failing in order to learn more! Then coming to Pune and testing on the most â€˜interestingâ€™ browser- Internet Explorer. Soon later, joining the Sony project and working with many seniors. The bloopers and the learnings, the fun and the serious moments, you can hear about all this and many other experiences of my first year at ThoughtWorks.
Theme: Experience at ThoughtWorks in my first year

title: Why Typography matters
content: We'll start with an introduction to the different typography terms and jargon, interpretation of fonts by the browsers. We'll talk about the different types of font faces and their relevance in different contexts, choosing fonts for specific content types. We'll also include font considerations when developing for multiple devices (responsive typography).

title: Lessons from Kollywood to TW
content: Few values/practices what we do here  at TW are not a rocket science.I'll be showing few clips from tamil movies and relate it with what we do.

title: Why Scala is 'the next enterprise language'
content: 10 reasons why you should consider Scala for your next project.

title: Scala is not static Ruby
content: I've  written production code on Java & Ruby.  I've started writing in Scala. After being so much comfortable with Ruby, coming to Scala made me ask many questions about both the languages.In this talk, we'll be discussing about  their concepts, the eco system, etc. with few code snippets in Ruby and Scala.At the end of the session you should be able to have a picture of the two languages  and if you are familiar with one of them, learning the other one should become easier.

title: The new Avatar of MAFIA in ThoughtWorks !!
content: We ThoughtWorkers have been playing MAFIA ever since we got through our interviews.Some of us feel it should be included in the on boarding process when a new joinee joins the ThoughtWorks family.We love the Mafia so much that we play it in bus, train and Airplane as well !!Some of us in pune have Mafia night where we get together only to play Mafia.Iâ€™m sure similar trends are followed in other offices as well.But its time we upgraded Mafia with some new Roles. And who better than us ThoughtWorkers to do that.So come join in to know about a few new Roles we have introduced and the Strategies with which we play.Roles like Vigilante, Suicide bomber, Joker - can be game changers.Its a lot more fun and a lot more interesting.

title: Lean Startup : Understanding your customers' requirements
content: A hands-on workshop involving over 20 people. Simulated delivery teams learn to run a profitable business by selling the customer a product built in iterations. Teaches the team to discover the customer's requirements better, to see the bigger picture through development, collaborate better to minimize waste and make assumptions wisely, and optimize the limited customer time available.

title: Next Gen Mobile Websites
content: Have you seen Delta Airlineâ€™s snappy new mobile website? What makes its user experience so cool that it almost outperformed Deltaâ€™s Android and iOS apps? What makes it so talked about on several tech & travel forums? Testimony from an enthused traveller - â€œDelta really takes flight with its speed and  streamlined user experienceâ€ù? Get insights into the makings of this fast and fluidic mobile website that loads in one shot and is ready to go !* Learn how Single Page Architecture (SPA) combined with HTML5 tools made this possible.* Understand the learnings and best practices of SPA and the common pitfalls. * Learn how to achieve impressive load performance even as your mobile website grows. * Even better, support your website in completely offline mode to avail important features. * Multi-platform support and how to deal with it.* How this app-like experience allows you to directly port it on platforms like BB as an App

title: Angular Awesomeness
content: What is AngularJs?Why it is awesome?How have we used it?AngularJs Gotchas.AngularJs Internals.Probably some hands on towards the end.
Speaker(s): Praveenram Balachander, Chandrasekar Swaminathan, Sanjana Bayya

title: Continuous Deployment using Chef
content: Advanced Chef - Hands-on sessionWe will share our learnings from GAP & Bluelabel :1. One click deployment from CI to EC2 instances.2. Load balancing services3. Managing migrations and artifacts.4. Handling version upgrades in all servers.Expectation: Familiarity with basic chef concepts.

title: How to derail a discussion
content: Being part of lengthy, fiery discussions I've observed many times how a discussion gets derailed and end up with no conclusion.It's interesting and slightly funny to know how it happens. Will be sharing five or six ideas to derail. :) :P

title: A cross-platform web-app with native experience - our story
content: Whenever a team has to develop an application that is targeted for a wide variety of mobile devices, the interesting yet difficult decision is whether to opt for a native or web-based application. We present the critical factors we considered before zeroing in on a web application. Also we discuss the numerous challenges we faced with our choice and the design alternatives we considered thereafter, like whether to use a responsive framework etc. We hope this serves as an eye-opener for your projects.
Speaker(s): Varun VM, Padmanabhan TV, Ganapathi Subramanian, Dhivya Dandapani, Deepa Sajani

title: I dont have time to learn
content: This is CDP time. We all set goals for next 6 - 12 months.Is it really possible to learn in way we expect. Most of us dont have passion, time to learn. Then, how to learn?

title: Beginners UI-Workshop - Enabling UI Development !!
content: Ever thought of acquiring some UI skills and then never got back to it ?Didnâ€™t get an opportunity to even get started ?What if you DID NOT have to go to a UI Developer to fix very small and easy UI issues ?Here is your chance to finally learn hands on UI development.The two of us (Vishnu/Shridhar) had an opportunity to learn UI development for a couple of Months, early on in our careers thanks to our Gurus in Pune Office. We also attended 2 UI-Boot Camps organized in Pune. So we would like to take this opportunity to share that knowledge with you.So join us in the UI-Workshop and get started !!Prerequisite: * You * Your Laptop. * Your interest to learn UI development.What will you learn? * HTML Basics:     - DOM     - Box-Model     - Block / Inline / inline-block     - Writing semantically meaningful HTML code. * CSS Basics:     - Basic CSS constructs required to beautify a page - Floats, Positions, Selectors, etc.Tentative plan for 90 min:* Introduction to DOM, HTML and CSS. - 10 min.* A few semantics before writing code - 10 min* Introducing the online tool which will be used for workshop - http://codepen.io/ and the simple assignment that we plan to work for.* 20 min cycles of building smaller components of the assignment which includes 15 min coding and 5 min demo/questions. - total 1 hour.* 10 min buffer time or Q & A as needed.* Your takeaway - Ability to write basic HTML and CSS code to build a web page.

title: How does a consumer decide?
content: Social platform has the power to change the market tide in your favor or against you. We embarked on a journey to bring together the scattered information about consumer choices and decision making into one place. In this session we shall discuss few of the challenges in understanding the social world. Several organizations have tried to understand the consumers and what drives them to make the choices they make.  We will discuss few of these methods that have been used to obtain consumer information and the insights we have from it and other studies.

title: Open feedback:  Is it risky
content: We did open feedback at Bluelabel and Purpose projects.  It was a very constructive exerciseWill be sharing the experience, tips to get it right..

title: 5 forever facts about thoughtworks
content: With my observation in last four quick years here, I have always found few things what people keep cribbing but continue to do.

title: Conquer the TDD battle in Android
content: Not following TDD while coding is like a crime in ThoughtWorks.Surely many have committed this crime while working with Android.Its time to enlighten ourselves and dive into writing tests for Android. Most Agile practitioners are convinced that it is not very easy to write Tests for Android. Moreover, the philosophy for TDD on Mobile Devices is different, since the components which we need to test are different.During testing main concern is how to test UI layers in Android? The frameworks are also not as evolved on Android. To tackle all these problems, we are here with a set of tools and guidelines to do effective TDD on Android. There are few ways people tried to enable TDD in Android as described below :   * Separate UI layer from logic, and just test logic   * Use a Framework like Roboelectric   * Separate UI layer from logic, write standard Junit test for logic layer and TDD using Instrumentation test framework for activities.We will explain the best out of these approaches - how to Test Drive your app, and the best practices.

title: From Mobile web to BlackBerry World - in less than a week!
content: With their new OS, BlackBerry has joined the bandwagon of platforms supporting Html5/Js as first class language. Using the BlackBerry Webworks framework, creating a mobile app from an existing mobile website is a piece of cake now! No third-party hybrid frameworks required and no performance degradations that you have to accept!Do you have a client who already has a mobile website and no app as yet on BB10? How about delighting them with a solution that costs minuscule and helps reap tons of benefits?Join us for a walkthrough of how you can go about development, deployment and publishing an app to BB World - in less than a week!

title: Advanced Game Controls on Android
content: When you're playing a racing game on your mobile, buttons to move left and right have become old school.What you want is, to tilt and turn your phone to navigate the traffic.Wonder how these things work ? Take Google Skymaps. Wonder how just pointing your phone towards a star in the sky gives you the name and the constellation.How do they do it ? Learn how you can use the Accelerometer and Magnetic Compass (and a couple of mathematical equations) to build something like this.

title: My first year at TW
content: Our transition from college to a working environment  - how we were and how we are now.TW Vs TWUOur experiences in TWU.How would we change TW if we can?Hits and misses that we encountered.

title: My First year in TW
content: Hey,I joined TW 6 months back. Used to work with CTS previously. I would like to share my experience especially on how different - different good it was from CTS

title: The musings of the THREE MADURAI MUSKETEERS
content: "Dear Sir/Madam" we would start, when we  were set to enter TW. But now we're like "Hi Dude!!" And we hope to be like "Machi !! Oru Quarter Sollen" in due course. Interested to hear more ?? Catch you @ Xconf S03E01 ..!  ( Rendu Pulli Oru Aachirya Kuri :D )
Speaker(s): Deepa Sajani J, Dhivya Dandapani, Ganapathi Subramanian V

title: Gamification and UX Design
content: We all love games. From the time we were born, we love to indulge ourselves in one game or another. This is so because games motivate us, keep us engaged, makes us fall in love with it and sometimes it even goes to the extent of making us addictive and go crazy about it. Fun, excitement and accomplishment are the main objectives of games. Just imagine, how would it be if we apply the similar gaming principle in the products that we develop. It would be interesting and rewarding as well. Applying these game principles to the non-game context is known as Gamification. Gamification is an evolving trend in UX design. This presentation aims in explaining the concepts of Gamification in detail along with relevant examples, methods and processes that can be applied to arrive at a solution that we design and develop for our customers.

title: In pursuit of Happiness
content: I recently read the book 'The Happiness Factor' by Kirk Wilkinson. It has had a profound impact on me - enabling me to change the way I look at life.  Being happy is a choice we all can make and not leave it to outcomes of circumstances.  In short - how to be happy no matter what ! I will share the secrets revealed in this book a.k.a the P-E-A-S-E-F-U-L approach that Kirk describes to find happiness.  Also, I think this book is a must read for every one.

title: 5 amazing facts about smartphones
content: Will be talking about how smartphones are necessity in today's era and not a luxury.And also about some amazing and useful smartphone apps that everybody should be aware of.

title: Android Command And Control
content: Android command and control is a service aimed at controlling your mobile device remotely.

title: Hacks and cracks to fool your friends
content: Simple nifty tricks of hacking and cracking be fun and how to fool your friends too...

title: Android automation workshop
content: Android automation using Calabash-Android and UIAutomator. About the tools:Calabash-android fires-up robotium based android automation adding the power of ruby and cucumber, while the new kid on the block UIAutomator is simply powerful cutting across application boundaries, though it needs time to grow to become a much more complete framework to house the power of BDD/Ruby.Plan:To deliver a workshop with one of these tools (UIAutomator being a recent revelation deserves to be favored more) and highlight which one could be more sensible and suit better given a project's context. All these thoughts are results of the experience (being) gained with my current Android project.

title: Mystery of the pool
content: The mystery starts from a production issue that we faced on Football Pools. We had certain requests hanging forever, whereas when the same request was made from another tab on the browser, it went through! With absolutely no help from the nginx or passenger logs, we were stumped!!In the talk, I will describe how we debugged the problem and pinpointed it to an issue in the pgpool - a connection pooling mechanism over postgres I will cover - basics around activerecord connections- basics around postgres connections- their mapping- their cleanup- some commonly misunderstood concepts- some debugging tips.- things we did to resolve the issue.

title: 3 annoying Clicks vs 1 swift Swipe - NextGen user experience implementation in Android
content: User Experience is more than just user interface (UI) design: Its a satisfaction experienced because the product was easy and pleasant to use. Swipe is the future of user interaction.Switching between chat windows on your Android ? Just Swipe it. Browsing the Play Store? Just Swipe it.Going through your emails ? Just Swipe it, and forget the annoying taps that you have to do to keep going back and forth !In Android, building app having a great UI is became a lot more easier with FRAGMENTS. Fragments are part of the recommended design by Google. Not just the â€ùclicksâ€ù , the pain of a developer is also reduced while building different apps for Tablet(BIG Screen) and Smartphone(small screen) using Fragments. We will be demonstrating the value they add to UI and how easily we can use them. Smart? yesElegant ? yesClean ? yesA 45 min demonstration on how to make Fluid UI Components on Android !

title: Why you should grunt when writing javascript code?
content: Javascript is an important programming language because it is language of the web browser. With the outreach of web from desktop computers to carry in pocket mobile devices the importance becomes much more. Hence day by day more and more libraries and frameworks are being developed in javascript. In this talk I will discuss about Grunt: The javascript task runner, its basic configuration, usage and advantages. We'll also see how to configure different tasks while using grunt.

title: Lessons on the design of things
content: I have been observing and trying to relate to why and how somethings have been designed fro sometime now. I'd like to share how some good and bad design of everyday things like a railway station platform to an X-ray machine in a hospital to desks in colleges can make or break things. And some abstract lessons that I have been able to take back to work.

title: Social Media Insights
content: â€œHey, you had gone for a movie yesterday right? I saw your pictures on Facebookâ€ù. We often get to hear statements like these. And, it is because social media and social networking has become a part and parcel of our lives. Twitter, Facebook, Google+, and the list goes on. With the sudden outburst in the use of social media, came the interests of researchers to find out more about its impacts. There have been many studies around this and the results are pretty striking. It has been proven that people are more likely to remember Facebook status than memorize a line from a book. It is a fact that a large number of candidates are rejected by employers because of something they have posted in these sites. It is fascinating to know that social media can track flu faster than control and prevention departments. Many such studies prove the pros and cons of social media. It is important for us to think about and understand these facts.

title: n different ways to sync data - story of amplify
content: In android, when it is required to sync data across 1000's of devices, there are lot of ways with which it can be solved. There are challenges in each of them too. This talk is about what are the different ways that were considered in Amplify project, which ones were tried out, and what are the learnings from them.Some buzz words which will be covered: push notifications, google cloud messaging, event sourcing, restful json service, long polling, xmppAlso, this will cover a brand new opinionated library, which is developed to solve this problem and going to be open-sourced!!Though, it is from a android project, applicable to all mobile platforms in general.

title: Click and go!
content: At Football pools, we are managing infrastructure using puppet-standalone. However, for managing which puppet scripts need to run on which VM, we are using a very simple mechanism ( a mapping of IPs to corresponding manifests). And all this is being orchestrated by "Go". Deployments are truly one click where infrastructure changes are propagated first and then code is deployed.Additionally, the infrastructure changes are also propagated and hence tested via various environments and only when they go green on all environments, are they picked up for the preprod/prod environments. Puppet code is also dry run to check for any possible anomalies before being actually run.All of this has helped in making deployments very smooth and hassle free. In this talk we share all of this and our learnings/experiences.

title: Sri Lanka: An unbiased overview
content: > Sinhalese and Tamils: What's the problem?> Are LTTE  and Prabhakaran a good people?> Why did Indira Gandhi supported LTTEs?> Why was Rajiv Gandhi killed?> Did genocide happen last year?> What's India's role?Come and get a complete overview about Sri Lanka issue.
